V.iii.12.B.1.b
.
TBI Events
The
TBI event
is a traumatically induced structural injury and/or physiological disruption of brain function resulting from an external force indicated by
at least one
of the following clinical signs immediately following the event:
any period of loss of consciousness or decreased consciousness
any loss of memory for events immediately before or after the injury
any alteration in mental state at the time of the injury (confusion, disorientation, slowed thinking, etc.)
neurological deficits, whether or not transient, or
intracranial lesion.
Notes
:
The TBI event has two necessary components: the
external force
and the
identifiable acute manifestations
of brain injury immediately following the external force.  Not all individuals exposed to an external force will have brain injury, and therefore, they will not meet the criteria for having a TBI event.
The acute manifestations may resolve without chronic disability, or a chronic disability may result.
Although unconsciousness or reduced consciousness is common in TBI events, these are
not
required.  Any one of the five signs will be sufficient.
